subject: Programming
title: Adjacency Lists and Matrices
description: One-minute skill: Adjacency Lists and Matrices.

hook.text: How do you store a graph in memory? Two main options, each with different strengths.

buildup.text: An adjacency list stores each node's neighbors in a list. Memory-efficient for sparse graphs.

discovery.text: An adjacency matrix uses a 2D grid. Checking if two nodes connect is instant but wastes memory.

twist.text: Most real-world graphs are sparse â€” few connections relative to possible ones. Lists usually win.

climax.text: The representation you choose affects every algorithm's speed and memory usage on that graph.

punchline.text: How you store the graph shapes how fast you traverse it.

quiz.question: When is an adjacency matrix preferred?
options: When the graph is dense with many edges
When the graph has very few edges
When the graph is a tree
